# publisher's description
The "home" is a quintessentially quotidian topic, yet one at the center of global concerns: Consumption habits, aesthetic preferences, international trade, and state authority all influence the domestic sphere. For middle-class residents of late-nineteenth- and early-twentieth-century Beirut, these debates took on critical importance. As Beirut was reshaped into a modern city, legal codes and urban projects pressed at the home from without, and imported commodities and new consumption habits transformed it from within. Drawing from rich archives in Arabic, Ottoman, French, and English―from advertisements and catalogues to previously unstudied government documents―A Taste for Home places the middle-class home at the intersection of local and global transformations. Middle-class domesticity took form between changing urbanity, politicization of domesticity, and changing consumption patterns. Transcending class-based aesthetic theories and static notions of "Westernization" alike, this book illuminates the self-representations and the material realities of an emerging middle class. Toufoul Abou-Hodeib offers a cultural history of late Ottoman Beirut that is at once global in the widest sense of the term and local enough to enter the most private of spaces.

Nr. 2252, 17 Jul 1917, Dr. Brode to Reichskanzler Dr. MichaelisIm Anschluss an den Bericht vom 28.v.M.J.Nr.1964 K.Nr. 136"Der Geschäftsführer des jetzt in Liquidation befindlichen Getreidesyndikats, Oberleutnant Dragoman Dr. Grobba [Dr. Fritz Grobba] hat dem kommandierenden General des XXII. Armeekorps Freiherrn von Kress über die diesjährige Ernte- und Verpflegungsaussichten einen Bericht erstatten [sic], dessen Abschrift ich mich beehre Euer Exzellenz zur hochgeneigten Einsicht anliegend zu überreichen. Was meinen Amtsbezirk bezw. die Etappeninspektion Jerusalem anlangt, so darf ich in folgendem die Ergebnisse dieses Berichts in kurzer Übersicht zusammenfassen. Ich bemerke dabei im Voraus, dass die von Oberleutnant Grobba kritisch verwerteten Zahlen, da auf türkischen Schätzungen beruhend, nicht unbedingt zuverlässig sein können, meines Erachtens jedoch wenigstens in ihren grossen Zügen annähernd richtig sein dürften, sodass sie die allgemeine Lage sowie deren zukünftige Entwicklung mit einiger Sicherheit erkennen lassen.Wie Euer Exzellenz aus den Vorberichten bekannt ist, hat im Bereich der IV. Armee die Verpflegungsfrage für die Zivilbevölkerung insofern eine endgültige Regelung gefunden als die **Zivil**behörde hiermit beauftragt worden ist. Die oberste Leitung ist jetzt dem Wali von Syrien (d.h. Damaskus) Tahsin Bey übertragen worden, der seinerseits wieder angeordnet hat, dass der Bedarf der Zivilbevölkerung durch die Etappeninspektionen durch (zwangsweisen) Ankauf sicher zu stellen ist. Auf diese Weise soll, wenigstens für einen bedeutenden Teil dieses Bedarfs, die  Fürsorge und die Verantwortung doch wiederum der Militärbehörde - Etappeninspektionen - zufallen.Der Etappeninspektion Jerusalem unterstehen:1. _Gänzlich_ d.h. sowohl bezüglich der Erhebung der Zehnten von der Ernte, wie des Verfügunsrechts über die Ernte: 1. Das selbständige Mutessariflik Jerusalem (Kazas: Jerusalem, Jaffa, Hebron, Berseba, Gaza) 2. Aus dem Berzirk der Provinz Syrien (Damaskus) der westliche Teil des Mutessarifliks Kerak (im Ostjordanlande) nämlich der eigentliche Kreis Kerak, der Zentralkreis Salt nebst dem Amtsbezirk Madeba.Anmerkung: Die Etappeninspektion umfasst demnach nicht den ganzen Teil _meines_ Amtsbezirks, zu dem das ganze Sandjak Kerak gehört.2. _Zumteil_ d.h. nur bezüglich Erhebung des (dopplten) Zehnten: + Von der Provinz Beirut, der Reg.Bezirk NablusDas vorraussichtliche Ernteergebnis in meinem Amtsbezirk, von Nablus also abgesehen, ist im eigentlichen Bezirk Jerusalem und im Ostjordanlande verschieden. Zunächst hat sich die Anbaufläche im Bezirk Jerusalem verringert, da ein Teil der Kazas Berseba und Gaza sich in Feindeshand befindet, ferner infloge der militärischen Einziehungen und Requisitionen Arbeitskräfte und Tiere fehlen und weil schliesslich dem Fellachen bei der drückenden Steuerlast und der nicht enden wollenden behördlichen Schikanen jede Lust fehlt, sein Land über seinen eigenen Bedarf hinaus zu bestellen. Beeinträchtigt wird das Ernteergebnis noch durch ungünstige Witterungseinflüsse. Diese Missstände fehlen im Ostjordanland gänzlich, dessen Bewohner im allgemeinen vom Militärdienste befreit sind, ihre Arbeitstiere besser dem militärischen Zugriff entziehen können und  schliesslich [...][...] Jerusalem unterstehenden Gebiete [...][...] sei es durch freien  Ankauf [...]Wird noch ein weiterer Zehnt von jedem Produkt zwangsweise angekauft, wie vorgeschlagen ist, so ermässigt sich der Fehlbetrag auf 1425000 kg Brotgetreide, 1220200 kg Viehfutter und 3093750 kg Trockengemüse. Dieser Fehlbetrag wäre dann wohl, da "freie" Aufkäufe im hiesigen Bezirk mit Rücksicht auf die Bedürfnisse der Zivilbevölkerung schwerlich mehr möglich sein würden, vom Norden her mit der Bahn heranzuschaffen. Bei diesen geplanten grossen Zwangsankäufen von insgesamt 3/8 der Ernte an Brotgetreide für die Armee bleibt der leidende Teil der Zivilbevölkerung. Ihr täglicher Bedarf ist von Djemal Pascha auf 250 gr Getreide (300 g Brot) festgesetzt worden; in Friedenszeiten verbrauchte der Landeseinwohner täglich 600 - 800 g Brot, so dass die jetzige Rationierung für ihn eine schwer erträgliche Einschränkung bedeutet. Es fragt sich aber, ob die Regierung überhaupt imstande sein wird, der Bevölkerung, die ihr zugemessene Menge verschaffen zu können. Nimmt man die gesamt Bevölkerungszahl der der Etappe Jerusalem unterstehenden Gebiete (Jerusalem, der westliche Teil von Kerak und Nablus) mit 612081 Seelen an - was vielleicht ziemlich genau stimmen könnte - , so würden diese jährlich  (250 g pro Kopf täglich) 55852300 kg Brotgetreide benötigen. Die Gesamternte an Brotgetreide (Weizen und Durra) beträgt aber überhaupt nur 5876800 kg, so dass diese also bei der geplanten knappen Rationierung nur einen geringen Ueberschuss von rund 3 Millionen kg lässt. Nun nimmt aber die Armee vorweg ihren Anteil von entweder 2/8 (nur von Weizen) gleich 10 Millionen kg oder aber vielleicht auch von 3/8 gleich 15 Millionen kg. Für die Zivilbevölkerung würde sich demnach ein Fehlbetrag von 7084301 bis zu 12084300 kg Brotgetreide ergeben.Dieser Fehlbetrag hat an sich nicht solche erschreckende Bedeutung, wie es auf den ersten Blick wohl erscheinen mag. Allerdings müsste ein etwaiger Ersatz von norden her mit der Eisenbahn herangeschafft werden, die neben ihren bisherigen unzulänglichen Leistungen für die Armeebedürfnisse schwerlich noch 12000t für die Zivilbevölkerung bewältigen könnte. Selbst wenn sie dazu imstand wäre, fragt es sich doch, ob die Ernteergebnisse in den Wilajets Damaskus oder Aleppo derartige sind, dass ein Betrag in dieser Höhe abgegeben werden könnte. Ich möchte es verneinen. Trotz alledem sehe ich aber die Lage nicht zu pessimistisch an; wohlgemerkt nicht etwa im Vertrauen auf eine etwaige gute Organisation und sparsame Wirtschaft - so etwas ist unter türkischer Leitung nun einmal unmöglich -, sondern weil trotz aller Statistik, schliesslich doch eine, wenn auch knapp ausreichende Menge an Lebensmitteln in unserem Besitz vorhanden ist. Jede hier nach einem einheitlichen Gesichtspunkte aufgestellte Statistik hat den Fehler, dass sie ein den Tatsachen nicht entsprechendes gleichmässiges Mass zugrundelegt. Die Bevölkerung lebt ja mit Vorliebe von Brot, wenn es aber nicht reicht, kann sie sich, wenigstens als Zusatz, der vor dem Verhungern schützt, mit anderen Produkten begnügen, wie Feigen, Kaktusfeigen, Apfelsinen, Weintrauben, Früchten usw. Die Bevölkerung ist ja im Grunde sehr genügsam und des öfteren in ihren grossen Teilen an Hungerperioden gewöhnt. Dazu kommt noch, dass die Verhältnisse in Stadt und Land verschiedenen sind. Gerade die Landbewohner werden Mittel finden, um einigermassen durchzukommen; nur für grössere Städte, vor allem Jerusalem, wird die Frage brennend werden. Hierfür besteht nach meiner Meinung die grösste Besorgnis. Trotz der schwierigen Ankaufs- und Transportverhältnisse - eine Eisenbahnlinie steht ja für die Versorgung Jerusalems aus dem Ostjordenlande nicht zur Verfügung - wäre es aber technisch möglich, auch diese Kalamatität zu bewältigen, wenn man eben nicht mit der geringen Leistungsfähigkeit und der Ungeschicklichkeit der türkischen Etappe rechnen müsste. Da auf dieser, wie bereits angeführt, letzten Endes doch die gesamte Fürsorge für die Verpflegung der Zivilbevölkerung ruht, die Etappe aber aller Voraussicht nach nicht einmal im Stande sein wird, den Heeresbedarf regelmässig zu decken, so wird sie notgedrungen die Zivilbevölkerung hungern lassen müssen. Der Schmuggelhandel wird ja die Leiden etwas mildern, die Wohlhabenderen Bevölkerungsteile werden sich ferner selbst genügend versorgen können. Die grosse Masse der Armen aber dürfte schwere Zeiten erleben. Unter diesen Umständen halte ich es keineswegs für unmöglich, dass man dann gelegentlich türkischerseits wiedereinmal die Frage wenigstens teilweisen Evakuierung von Jerusalem aufrollt.Die in Liquidation befindliche Getreidekommission hat auch jetzt noch der Regierung ihre Dienste zur Verfügung gestellt und hoffe, mit den ihr zu Transportzwecken über-lassenen 500 Eseln monatlich 125000 kg Getreide heranschaffen zu können. Dies würde ungefähr etwas mehr als der vierte Teil des monatlichen Bedarfs sein (250 g täglich für etwa 53000 Seelen). Die Getreidekommission wird daher zunächst, um wenigstens etwas vollkommen zu erreichen, den Bedarf der Wohltätigkeitsanstalten und bestimmter Bevölkerungsteile, darunter auch die deutsche Kolonie, gänzlich decken. Die Vorarbeiten hierzu sind im Gange.Wie die Sache sich nun weiter entwickeln wird bleibt abzuwarten."Dr. Brode- 3 copies attached. The report and the attachments are also sent to the embassy and the consular agents in Constantinople, Beirut, Aleppo, Damascus. The attachment is also sent to the command of the 22. Army Corps.

argument: in addition to cultural and social identities class should be seen as a frame of reference in the early 20th century, that is in Marxist terminology: class consciousness or class-for-itself
            
            Focus of this paper: lower-class activism
            - CUP discovered boycott of foreign goods as means to mobilize a large public (s.2). 
            - an empire-wide strike movement started with the port workers and boatmen (s.2f.). Together exaggerated expectations amongst the empires subjects this caused the oppression and persecution of public demonstrations by the CUP (s.5)
            - foreign (Afghan and Maghrebi) guards employed by landowners as guards of their estates seem to have developed a "strong shared identity" (s.4) in their struggle for higher wages, that could involve the destruction of the property they were meant to protect (s.4). Constant violence caused such policies as the deportation of foreigners who were convicted of any crime (s.4)
            - local politicians and intellectuals discovered rural unrest as a means of politics against the Ottoman administration, for or against the CUP, against the European influence and Jewish immigration, for the improvement of rural living conditions (s.6). Use of the newspaper filastin towards this aim (s.6).
            
            The paper starts with an assessment of the perspective and emphasis on the emergence of a new urban middle class, that is neither al-ʿāmma nor al-khāṣṣa or al-aʿyān as the result of modernisation processes. The Young Turk Revolution led to a political mobilization of this class and wide popular participation in the public sphere that found its expression in many demonstrations and was coined "civic Ottomanism" by Michelle Campos.(S.1) There are characteristic features that allow to conceptualize a middle class: set of institutions and practices used by these actors (such as the print media, clubs, demonstrations, and petitions) as well as a rhetoric inspired by a mixture of authoritarian modernisation ideology, populism, liberal values, and utilitarianism. By the 1920s and 1930s these middle classes gradually merged with the aʿyān (s.2).
title: Lower-Class Activism in the District of Jerusalem in the Wake of the Young Turk Revolution, 1908-1914

# author's abstract
During the First World War, the Ottomans undertook a pan-Islamism propaganda campaign through the newspaper al-Sharq (published by Djemal Pasha in Damascus) to motivate its Arab subjects to support the Ottoman struggle against the Entente powers. To this end, many articles and news items appeared in al-Sharq to inspire Muslim unity around the figure of the caliph. Unity was presented as a crucial part of saving Muslims; disasters were predicted should the Ottoman Empire fall to the ‘infidels’. Sharīf Ḥusayn and his followers were explicitly or implicitly accused of splitting the umma and rendering the Ḥijāz and the remainder of independent Muslim territories vulnerable to British and other European imperialists. In 1916, Sharīf Ḥusayn launched a revolt in Mecca against the Ottoman Caliph and established a periodical, al-Qibla, to target the same audience. In al-Qibla, Ḥusayn presented the Committee of Union and Progress as amoral and irreligious usurpers of the caliph’s authority, and therefore undeserving of allegiance. In this article I analyse the discourse of the two competing sides by examining their propaganda on issues such as loyalty to the caliph, the unity of the Muslims and the formation of alliances with the Great Powers. I argue that Islam shaped the propaganda battle between the Ottomans and the sharīf to a greater extent than did Arabism or Turkism.
title: Visions of Islamic Unity: A Comparison of Djemal Pasha’s al-Sharq and Sharīf Ḥusayn’s al-Qibla Periodicals

Unlike his article on censorship, which confuses publication dates and calendars and, thus, mis-dates the issues of Thamarāt, the references in his PhD thesis are correct.
The focus of his work is on the early years, as on page 216 of some 350, he still writes on the early days of Hamdi's governorship (1880!)

Focus: the first 5-6 years of publication. The table of contents already signifies the focus of the thesis: the establishment and the first year of Thamarāt’s publication 1875, take up 34 pages (35-78), the following five years, 1876-80, take up another 102 pages (79-181), then follow some 113 pages for the almost two decades between 1880-98 (182-295), of which the first 40 pages are dedicated to 1880-81, after which Cioeta jumps to the late 1880s and then to 1896 in a shift from chronologic depiction to topic based snippets. In addition, he repeatedly returns to the 1880s (e.g. 278). The final decade, 1898-1908, is treated within less than 40 pages (296-332). Altogether this set-up dedicates more than half of the thesis to the first 5-6 of 33 years of publication, without ever commenting on or explaining this choice. This is particularly worrying as the changes in the legal framework of 1894 or the split of Beirut from Damascus as an independent province in 1888, might have impacts that are not really discussed.

Methodology: narrative description along the almost sole source of Thamarāt itself, always identifying the paper and its articles with the editors, ʿAbd al-Qādir al-Qabbānī and later Aḥmad Ḥasan Ṭabbāra. Over long stretches, the thesis reads like an intellectual biography of al-Qabbānī.

Critique: all the controversies with other papers or the authorities are solely reported through Thamarāt’s articles, without commenting on this limitation and bias. This is specifically unfortunate, as at least the most audible opponent, al-Bashīr, is readily available.

abstract: […]"the great ‘coup d’Etat’ which took place in Turkey on the 24th July occupied all minds and arouses every emotion with the proclamation of the Constitution, in Damascus as in all other important centres in the Empire. Among its results worthy of remark here were (a) celebrations and festivities (b) dismissal or resignation oaf notoriously corrupt  officials (c) formation of clubs and associations (d) parliamentary elections (e) reforms in various governmental departments. (f) release or rehabilitation of political exiles or persons [xxx].Rejoicings and joyful manifestation are only coming now to an end, after lasting more than two months: more than 25 well organized great meetings were held int he different quarters of the city, mostly attended by several thousands [sic] demonstrators and spectators, and hundreds of speeches were delivered, all condemning autocracy as despotic & tyrannical and eulogizing liberty and constitutional government. About £2000 were spent on the festivities and had not notables of Damascus with the young Turks lately recommended their cessation they might have continued for another month or more. It is to be remarked with pleasure that all these gathering & demonstrations were conducted most orderly without any dispute or ill feeling among those who assembled.Many corrupt officials were either dismissed or withdrew themselves.The Alaybey of Gendarmerie, the Chief of Police, the Muhassebeji, six Caimacams of Cazas, Moh.d P. Adm [Muḥammad Pasha al-ʿAẓm] of Idara Mejliss with about 30 other minor officials vacated their posts, mostly to the general satisfaction of the public and it is debated now among ‘Young Turkey’ adherents whether it would be right to punish the officials who were led to bribery by the littleness of their pay & its frequent irregularity. Doubtless the proper course will be followed in leaving this matter to the jurisdiction  of Parliament when it assembles, and the ignorious[?] dismissal of the more corrupt, rapacious & outrageous among officials suffices for the moment. Moreover, the vacancies are not being easily filled up by really good substitutes, for such persons are at present  rare, and often unwilling to serve. Damascus Clubs & associations, besides the Union & Progress number now five viz Hurriyet, Ulema, Medical, Commercial, Free Ottoman besides a Shoemaker guild. the first two are showing much activity wh.[ich] is likely to excite mutation . The misapprehension & with uncalled solicitude Ulema are anxious to comcure [?sic] & uphold Islam against the liberal views of the Young Turks, while the latter have no intention at present to interfere with religious precepts. The first point of dispute was about women’s wear which the Ulema wanted to be cut on a very simple mode, one piece enveloping the whole body, and the liberals denied them the right of interfering with this matter which should be regarded as pertaining to individual free choice. In this campaign the Ulema were defeated but not without their rivals using threats of applying force.There is little record as to practical work effected [?] by other clubs though their moral influence cannot be other than good.The Parliamentary elections are under preparation the last two months and in some cazas the voters have already voted for the electors, but in Damascus city this process will begin in a week’s time. It is not even announced yet how many deputies will represent this Vilayet in the Parliament but it is supposed that they will be seven or eight. The Hauran people still reject their privilege to elect a deputy and the efforts of the government in dissuading them from this self-inflicted loss seem to be futile. The Mutessarif of Kerak lately resigned on grounds of health, but before doing so had been able to set going a local society or club for instruction of the people of his district who indeed are little  less backward &ignorant than this of Hauran.The reforms in the various departments of the government proceed slowly. The Municipality suppressed most improperly awarded pensions paid to persons doing nothing for it  and succeeded in amassing about £3000 through various economies. The Public Instruction Department formed a new chamber to consider the reorganization of the educational system in this Vilayet. In the departments no special reforms worth mentioning have been introduced but many are being talked of & discussed. The political exiles who had been releases or rehabilitated included many persons of rank, both military and civil. Mushir Fuad Pasha’s release was the occasion of great demonstrations in Damascus, but the rehabilitation of others, with a few exceptions, was not publicly noticed, for this disgraces persons were always enjoying personal freedom  and a very few persons knew that they were ‘Ikamet Mamours’ [iqāma maʾmūr]. The chief names among these were, Nouri P. Ferik of Cavalry, another Ferik called Nouri Pasha sent to live here without duties, Ferik Ibrahim Pasha (those three Feriks kept for Constantinople), Ferik Lt. Osman P., Liva Behjet Pasha (those two died recently), Colonel Bedri Bey (now of Liva Bedri P. in Constantinople). The Maàriz Mushiri [?] & his assistant, and many minor officials or private persons; such as members of the Bedr Khan family, numbering more than a hundred. Further as reported in desp. No. 32, the Ismailians subjected to religious persecution were pardoned. Happily no sort of disorder or riotous intention was displayed here for the purpose of releasing prisoners and ordinary criminals generally, as took place in some other places."Ḥijāz railway was completed in seven years and inaugurated on 1 Sep 1908. four of the five battalions employed for earthworks on the line were allowed to return to their garrisons. "about 1400 of these battalions on expiry of service were disbanded. Moreover, the four battalions of the 40th Reg, sent to Medina from this Army Corps in June last, to guard the line, are also ordered back to their headquarters. At present only two battalions are to be kept there to take care of the line as regards repairs & protection." No aspirations to commence construction beyond Medina due to increasing Bedouin raids "Public security in the Vilayet has been during the quarter satisfactory and order was properly kept. The Bedouins have been quiet & peaceful during the summer, and only on two or three occasions made petty rais & drove or carried away animals or goods but the spoils were restored to their owners without great difficulties." Druze and Bedouins seem under the spell of the government and calmly wait for the implementation of the promised reforms"the crops this year were in general very good and the grain harvest in most of the districts of the Province was exceptionally abundant. The apricot produce was above the average while walnuts were much below. All prices of fruit and cereals are still high and the peasants this year will do well. An exception might be mentioned as  as regards locusts which made a perceptible damage in the Kalamoun district but had a very slight effect in some other Cazas. But the loss to the Vilayet in general has been small.As respects trade, no special remarks need be made; strikes at Beirut at the Customs and on local railways have produced only exiguous loss here. With reference to the latter we may note that public opinion judges that the smaller employés  were underpaid, while the profits of the Company & of its directors were considerable and the public at the same time ill served.Public health has been satisfactory on the whole this summer, but the Ain Fijeh water has not been received the general approbation anticipated which is to be regretted, as theres is absolute proof the it is the best & purest spring water of al this neighbourhood. Its distribution to all quarters of the city proceeds slowly."

#press and Hamidian censorship?
- the author makes strong revisionist claims and argues for a more nuanced image of the practices of censorship. But since her source base seems to be restricted to a single journal, which itself was never banned from publication, she does not have enough evidence for a much broader claim.
- her work does not make mine redundant. She does not provide an in-depth account of Ottoman legislation pertaining to printed material, even though the table of contents gave this impression (Her table of selected regulations is based on a 1938 Turkish work).
#author's description
This is a study of state and society as both were articulated and negotiated in the Ottoman popular press, focusing on the cheap, illustrated serials produced for women and their families 1876-1909. These gazettes cut more deeply into non-elite society than has previously been suggested in the scant mentions of the popular press in precedent historiography of the Hamidian era.
By analysing and interpreting the late-Ottoman popular press, particularly that part written for and increasingly by women, I present shifting notions of Islam, Ottoman modernity, civic identity, and female gender at a time when these terms became increasingly alien as they were abstracted into the realm of contesting ideologies. At the same time, ironically, these notions became more quotidian and practical, more intimately woven into the daily lives of subjects of one of the last land-based, multi-ethnic empires to survive into the twentieth century. As Ottomans worked these ideological contests into their daily conflicts, choices, and actions, they constructed mentalites which I will attempt to portray, in part, through this study of one meeting ground of the ideological and the quotidian, the women's press of Istanbul in the Hamidian era.
My sources are the run of Hanimlara mahsus gazete with comparative reference to other publications for women and of more general interest, both in support of and in opposition to the Hamidian regime. In addition, I use monographs written by Hanimlara mahasus gazete's publisher, editors, and writers, and essays by their predecessors and contemporaries on issues of relevance to the gazette. From the Ottoman Basbakanlik archives I have drawn several hundred documents relating to publishing permission, censorship, and closure of magazines. I use these in concert with press laws of this period to reconstruct, briefly, state-press relations. I interweave research on architecture, markets and manufacture, photography, and the politics of display in an effort to place the popular press within the wider context of late-Ottoman political and intellectual histogriography. Finally, throughout the dissertation I make a first cut at incorporating comparative material from European, Egyptian, and Far Eastern historiography.
title: Unimagined communities: State, press, and gender in the Hamidian era

“Wheat Riots at Baghdad, Major Bemsay’s No 864 reporting on”
Enclosing the despatch by the Consul General in Baghdad

#Inclosure no. 1
Bagdad, 21 Sep 1908, Major Ramsay to Government of India
“Sir,
In continuation of my letter [No. 847] dated the 14th instant, I have the honour to report that the telegram of which the purport was given in the third paragraph of that letter appears to have been malevolently added to in Bagdad before it was made partially public. The original telegram, as received from Constantinople, contained no reference to the use of military force against the Young Turk Committee in provincial towns. The perverted version of the telegram was made known in Karbala.
2. On the 16th instant there was a riot in which some of the grain stored were pillaged. The exportation of wheat has for some time been prohibited, and on the 14th and 15th instant it was rumoured that a certain Jew had received permission from Constantinople to export some wheat and that he was going to load it on the 16th. On that morning a crowd went to the Vali to protest. It is said that the Vali assured them that no order had been issued allowing the export of wheat, and it is said that the Vali strengthened his assurance by saying that when an attempt to load wad made it would time for the people to make serious complaints. It is not possible to know exactly what was said, much less what was understood, but the crowd went straight off to the grain stores and took what they could carry. It was at first reported that the loss was enormous, but the estimates have since been largely reduced, and I am inclined to think that the loss cannot have been very great. The populace took what it could during an interval of about an hour and a-half, but the entrances to the store are narrow and they were choked by the crowd, so much so that a number of the rioters found it convenient to pass their stolen wheat over the wall. In these circumstances a very large quantity of wheat cannot have been removed. Messrs. Lynch’s experience is that with the best arrangement, and all wheat in bags, not more than 100 tons could be removed in an hour and a-half. A very small proportion of this can have been taken by a struggling crowd.
One man claimed compensation for about 600l. [£ 600] worth of wheat which he said he held on behalf of a British subject and which he said had been pillaged during the riot. I went to his place of business to examine his books, and he then said that he did not want the intervention of the Consulate and would settle the matter himself.
Another man who claimed compensation on behalf of Messrs. Andrew Weir and Co. of London had to admit that he could not produce proof that any Court would accept.
A third man’s claim is still under consideration, but from what I have heard I am pretty fairly certain that it will not stand examination.
There is no doubt that all of these men have lost wheat, but they cannot prove that it was the property of British subjects.
3. There are a number of deserters about Bagdad who are a continual source of <pb/> danger to peaceful people. I understand that the Commander of the VIth Army Corps has written to Constantinople to say that it is necessary either to come to some settlement with them or to shoot them.
4. The Young Turk Committee at Karbala has made all the officials publicly swear loyalty to the Constitution, but the Mutessarif shows a strong dislike to interference, and the Vali of Bagdad is said to be troubled with many differences between the two parties.

I have, &c. …

abstract: The essay explores the use of digital history for the systematic study of the periodical press in the late Ottoman Eastern Mediterranean (1906 –1918) as a discursive field. It evaluates the methodological and practical challenges of digital history as rooted in the socio-technical infrastructures of the Global North when applied to the Global South. It does so using a case study of four Arabic journals from Baghdad, Beirut, Cairo, and Damascus. After outlining the need for building a corpus and the challenges presented by this effort, this article explores a digital corpus of a total of circa 2.65 million words through (social) network analysis and stylometric authorship attribution.
